newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Thailand's Amnuay stresses need for good government.
newsitem.headline: Thailand's Amnuay stresses need for good government.

text.p: Thailand's caretaker deputy prime minister and foreign minister, who is considering an offer to join the new coalition government, said on Tuesday corruption is a losing proposition for Asian countries.

"I think it's their own affairs and they would realise that in order to make a good governance, to deliver the goods to the people...and to promote prosperity in their countries, they will have to have a good government," Amnuay Viravan told Reuters after speaking at a plenary session of the World Economic Forum.

"Otherwise, you would be at the losing end because we are now in a competitive world and if you are operating at a higher cost -- either cost by the government or by the business -- then you cannot succeed," he said.

Thai caretaker prime minister Banharn Silpa-archa was forced to resign and call elections after a no-confidence debate in which he and his party were accused of corruption and mismanagement. He won the debate but chose a week later to dissolve parliament for fresh elections.

Amnuay said issues of corruption had not been raised at meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), which groups Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
"I don't think that this is something which has been really brought up to a formal discussion," he said.

Amnuay said on Monday he was considering an offer from the winning New Aspiration Party, which is expected to form the next government as part of a coalition, to take charge of Thailand's economic policy.
If he were to take the post, he said, it would be as an independent without party affiliations.
